nodes.bodyText:
First I was confused with why are we visiting end points... but then looked it up in code.
Should the javadocs of this method be somehow changed as we're not supposed to search for theme information from "end points" anymore ? I mean that first we check for the theme annotation from the AppShellConfiguration and then if that is not found, we can search the "end points" and then make it fail if it is discovered there ?

Based on the code here, I think the error is thrown only if the theme is discovered >1 times on any of the following things that are collected as EndPoint:

Route
WebComponentExporter or WebComponentExporterFactory
UIInitListener
VaadinServiceInitListener
HasErrorParameter

And I don't think the theme should be on any of those classes anymore (?) even 1 time, so this code seems off now.

Doesn't this go into adding app theme support for exported web component ?
Not sure it is OK for now or we should just have TODOs in place until we have tests that validate things...
Or if we add the support at the same time we should then at least draft the issues for web component support accordingly and make sure this PRs commit message acknowledges all the additions.
I think the class javadocs need to be updated as they now don't refer to the application theme and its folder in any way, which is the recommended way to go.
What is an application theme ? (+ missing a dot)

Java components exported as WCs using Flow’s WebComponentExporter apply the theme’s styles automatically inside the exported WC and css defined in document.css (e.g. @font-face declarations) to the document itself.

The fusion views will instead apply the theme in another way that will go into a base class that views extend

For the class level javadocs something like: Defines the theme to use for the application. Should be present only once for an app, in the `AppShellConfiguration` class.

The {@code value} property defines the name of the application theme. When the theme is present inside the project, it maps to the {@code frontend/theme/}/ folder or alternatively to a folder inside the static resources of a jar file, like {@code src/main/resources/META-INF/resources//}. The application theme is always based on Lumo theme and this is the recommended way to theme applications starting from Flow 6.0 and Vaadin 19.
